text: date: tue 11/7/2000 8:10 am from: kevin jarvis (kjarvis@sekani.com)to: newsfeedback@wired.comsubject: retrofitting the film industrythat's great madstone will try to put digital projection into theaters. but at the same time they are forgeting about a lot of things.("retrofitting the film industry," nov. 3, 2000) such as international distribution. hollywood certainly just doesn't show movies in this country and then forget about them once the run has completed in this country. they sell and distribute the film overseas and recoup a serious profit from international distribution.the strange thing about many theaters in other countries is that they still show films on ancient projectors going as far back as the 1940s. theater owners in these countries would die to have a platter system projector, the 35mm projection system used in many u.s. theaters. you have to think, if these exhibitors can't even afford the current film projection system ... how can they afford digital technology? and you cannot say madstone doesn't plan to sell its films overseas either.this shows how universal 35mm film is in the world. one format, one viewing system. 35mm can be played anywhere on the same system in the world. digital cannot do that. something to think about.
